entry.title: Re: How to export business role template component in mass
entry.content:
Dear customer,

 

Thanks for reaching out.

It is not possible to mass extract component of business role template via the business role template application in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. But as a workaround, you can use the Fiori Apps Library, select the Product Suite as S/4HANA Public Cloud, select Leading Business PFCG Role column and Application Component column in Column Display Settings to display the business role template and component, then click Download button to mass export in excel.

Hope this helps clarify the issue.

 

Best regards,

Jannie

entry.content:
Dear colleagues,

As part of our ongoing platform transformation, we are migrating to Sales Cloud V2 and S/4HANA. Initial testing within our sandbox environment has confirmed successful access to the Sales Cloud V2 APIs.

For productive use, we aim to establish a secure and scalable integration architecture by leveraging SAP Integration Suite in conjunction with the Cloud Connector. This setup is intended to enable on-premise clients to proactively consume Sales Cloud V2 APIs.

The envisioned scenario involves external calls initiated from on-prem systems, with responses returned from the cloud ‚Äî for example, accessing data related to the Business Partner object.

We would like to validate whether this architecture is technically feasible and aligns with best practices for hybrid connectivity and secure API exposure.

entry.title: Re: ABAP2XLSX: Generic method to load any file into an in...
entry.content:
The demo program you mentioned gave me a clue as to how to make my code more efficient. Here I've created a function that does exactly what I need and that performs well thanks to the GET_HIGHEST_ROW and GET_HIGHEST_COLUMN methods. 

The returned table has the following fields:
WORKSHEET 
ROW
COL
VALUE

FUNCTION zload_table_from_excel .
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(IV_FILENAME) TYPE  CHAR1024
*"     REFERENCE(IV_BEGIN_COL) TYPE  I DEFAULT 1
*"     REFERENCE(IV_BEGIN_ROW) TYPE  I DEFAULT 1
*"     REFERENCE(IV_END_COL) TYPE  I DEFAULT 30
*"     REFERENCE(IV_END_ROW) TYPE  I DEFAULT 5000
*"     REFERENCE(IT_EXCLUDED_TABS) TYPE  OIJ02_DS_SEL_INTRANGE_T
*"       OPTIONAL
*"  EXPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(ET_INTERN) TYPE  ZALSMEX_TABLINE_T
*"  EXCEPTIONS
*"      ERROR
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
  DATA:
    lv_max_col     TYPE zexcel_cell_column,
    lv_max_row     TYPE int4,
    lv_value       TYPE string,
    ls_intern      TYPE zalsmex_tabline,
    lv_current_ws  TYPE sy-tabix,
    lv_current_row TYPE sy-tabix,
    lv_current_col TYPE sy-tabix.

  DATA(lo_reader) = CAST zif_excel_reader( NEW zcl_excel_reader_2007( ) ).
  DATA(lo_excel) = lo_reader->load_file( iv_filename ).

  TRY.

      DO.

        ADD 1 TO lv_current_ws.

        DATA(lo_worksheet) = lo_excel->get_worksheet_by_index( lv_current_ws ).
        IF lo_worksheet IS NOT BOUND.
          EXIT.
        ENDIF.

        IF lv_current_ws IN it_excluded_tabs AND it_excluded_tabs IS NOT INITIAL.
          CONTINUE.
        ENDIF.

        lv_max_col =  lo_worksheet->get_highest_column( ).
        IF iv_end_col IS SUPPLIED AND iv_end_col < lv_max_col.
          lv_max_col = iv_end_col.
        ENDIF.
        lv_max_row =  lo_worksheet->get_highest_row( ).
        IF iv_end_row IS SUPPLIED AND iv_end_row < lv_max_row.
          lv_max_row = iv_end_row.
        ENDIF.

        lv_current_row = iv_begin_row.
        DO.

          ADD 1 TO lv_current_row.
          IF lv_current_row GT lv_max_row.
            EXIT.
          ENDIF.

          lv_current_col = iv_begin_col.
          DO.

            ADD 1 TO lv_current_col.
            IF lv_current_col GT lv_max_col.
              EXIT.
            ENDIF.

            CLEAR: ls_intern-zvalue.

            lo_worksheet->get_cell( EXPORTING
                                       ip_column = lv_current_col
                                       ip_row    = lv_current_row
                                     IMPORTING
                                       ep_value  = lv_value
                                   ).

            IF lv_value IS NOT INITIAL.
              ls_intern-zworksheet = lv_current_ws.
              ls_intern-zrow       = lv_current_row.
              ls_intern-zcol       = lv_current_col.
              ls_intern-zvalue     = lv_value.
              APPEND ls_intern TO et_intern.
            ENDIF.

          ENDDO.

        ENDDO.

      ENDDO.
    CATCH zcx_excel .
      RAISE error.
  ENDTRY.
ENDFUNCTION.

entry.title: Integrating Joule into Eclipse IDE without re-installing ‚Äì A Quick Guide
entry.content:
With SAP‚Äôs recent focus on developer productivity, Joule is becoming an integral part of our toolset. If you‚Äôre already working with Eclipse IDE and ABAP Development Tools (ADT), you might be wondering how to bring Joule into your existing setup without starting from scratch.

In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through a simple process to enable Joule in Eclipse if you already have an older version installed.

Why Joule in Eclipse?

Joule brings AI assistance right into your familiar development environment. Gone are the days when boring coding used to happen. Now we have Joule to explain the code, finding out the dependencies like which ABAP objects( DB tables, CDS views, interfaces, etc) are referred in long code lines which never ends, Joule can understand your code and write ABAP units for you in no time.

Less talking, more work. Let's follow the steps below and get yourself introduce to one and only "Joule". 

Step 1 ‚Äì Update ADT Patch

Ensure that your Eclipse has the latest ABAP Development Tools (ADT) patch.

  1. Open Eclipse.

  2. Go to Help ‚Üí Install New Software.
     

  3. Add the latest ADT update site:

    https://tools.hana.ondemand.com/latest
     

  4. Select the updates and proceed with installation.

Step 2 ‚Äì Update Eclipse Version

To access the Joule menu, Eclipse itself needs to be updated.

  1. Go to Eclipse menu ‚Üí About Eclipse IDE.

  2. Click the Update button.

  3. Wait for Eclipse to fetch and apply updates.

That‚Äôs It!

Once the update is complete, you‚Äôll notice the Joule option appearing in your Eclipse menu.

entry.title: BP Legal Form changes not updating KNA1-GFORM
entry.content:
We are facing an issue in our MDG on S/4HANA landscape related to BP ‚Üí Customer (CVI) synchronization.

  • CVI customizing and mapping (Legal Status ‚Üî Legal Form) is already in place and checked.

  • Other field updates (e.g., name, address) are working fine and replicating properly.

  • There are no errors in activation or replication logs  the update just doesn‚Äôt reach KNA1.

Any guidance, experience, or reference to OSS notes would be very helpful.

entry.title: Re: SAC - Linking multiple models
entry.content:
Yes, you're correct! In SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), you can link multiple BW queries as models using the Link Dimensions feature and then combine the data from these models into a single story. However, after linking the models, you need to handle how the measures and dimensions from the different models are merged and displayed.

Here‚Äôs a step-by-step approach and suggestions for how to implement the story from multiple BW queries in SAC.

1. Create Models from BW Queries

To start, you need to connect the BW queries to SAC. Once connected, you can use the Link Dimensions feature to link different models that correspond to the different BW queries you want to integrate into a single story.

Steps to Create Models:

  1. Connect SAC to your BW system:

    • Go to the Connections section in SAC and establish a connection to your SAP BW system.

    • Use SAP BW Live Data Connection to link the BW system to SAC.

  2. Create Models from BW Queries:

    • Open the Models section in SAC.

    • Click + to create a new model.

    • Select the BW Query as the data source.

    • Choose your BW Query from the list.

    • Define the dimensions and measures that you need in the model.

  3. Repeat this for all 4 BW Queries:

    • You need to repeat this process to create separate models for each BW Query (assuming each query represents a different dataset you want to use in the story).

2. Link Dimensions in SAC

The Link Dimensions feature in SAC allows you to link dimensions from different models to create a unified view of the data. This is essential when you are working with data from multiple models (i.e., 4 BW queries in your case).

Steps to Link Dimensions:

  1. Create a New Story:

    • After creating the models, go to the Stories section in SAC and create a new story.

  2. Add a New Widget/Chart:

    • Drag and drop a widget (like a table, bar chart, etc.) onto the story canvas.

  3. Select the First Model:

    • Choose the first model (one of the 4 BW queries) and select the dimensions and measures you want to display in the widget.

  4. Link Dimensions:

    • Now, click on the Link Dimensions button.

    • Link the common dimension between the models. For example, if you have a common dimension like Customer, Time, or Product, you will link those dimensions across the different models.

    For example, if you have Model A, Model B, Model C, and Model D, and they all have a common dimension Customer:

    • In the dimension tab of Model A, select the Customer dimension.

    • In Model B, select the Customer dimension as well.

    • SAC will automatically link the Customer dimension between these models based on the shared values.

  5. Link Measures:

    • After linking the dimensions, you can select the measures from each model. These can be individual measures, like Sales, Quantity, or Cost, depending on your data.

    SAC will match the data on the linked dimensions and combine the measures from the different models.

    If you want to include multiple measures from different models (e.g., Sales from Model A and Cost from Model B), SAC will combine them based on the common linked dimension.

3. Handling Different Measures and Dimensions

Now, after linking the dimensions, you need to ensure that you properly handle the measures and dimensions in your storyboard (the SAC canvas):

  • Measures:

    • When linking models, SAC allows you to choose measures from different models.

    • Each model will bring its own set of measures (e.g., Sales, Quantity, Cost), but you will be able to drag and drop them into the same chart or table based on the linked dimensions.

    • If there are overlapping measures with the same name, SAC will append them with model identifiers (like Measure from Model A, Measure from Model B) to avoid any conflicts.

  • Dimensions:

    • The common dimensions (like Customer, Product, Region, Time) will be available across all models once linked.

    • Ensure that the dimension types (e.g., time, location, customer) are consistent across the models to avoid confusion when combining them.

Example Scenario:

Imagine you have 4 BW queries:

  • Model A: Sales data (Measures: Sales Amount, Quantity)

  • Model B: Cost data (Measures: Cost, Profit)

  • Model C: Customer data (Dimensions: Customer, Region)

  • Model D: Time data (Dimensions: Year, Month)

Here‚Äôs how you can handle this:

  • Link common dimensions: Link Customer from Model C and Region from Model C to the corresponding dimensions in the other models.

  • Add measures from different models:

    • You can have Sales Amount and Quantity from Model A, Cost and Profit from Model B, while also adding the Customer and Region dimensions from Model C, and Year and Month from Model D.

This will give you a combined table or chart showing sales, cost, and profit by customer and region, over time.

4. Considerations When Linking Multiple Models

  • Data Compatibility: Make sure the dimensions you're linking are of the same type and have consistent formatting across all the models. For example, if one model has Year in a number format and another has it in a string format, SAC may not be able to link them correctly.

  • Performance: Be mindful of performance when linking a large number of models. It can impact the query execution time and the user experience, especially with large data sets.

  • Aggregation: When linking measures across models, SAC will automatically aggregate the data based on the linked dimensions. Ensure that the granularity of the measures aligns across the models, especially when it comes to time-based data (e.g., monthly vs. yearly).

5. Finalizing and Displaying in Story

Once you‚Äôve linked the dimensions and selected the appropriate measures, you can finalize the story:

  • Add visualizations like charts, tables, or KPI widgets.

  • Use filters to allow users to slice and dice the data based on different dimensions.

  • Customize the layout to present a unified, comprehensive view of the data from all 4 BW queries.

Summary

  • Step 1: Create models for each of the 4 BW queries in SAC.

  • Step 2: Use the Link Dimensions feature to connect the models by their common dimensions.

  • Step 3: Add the relevant measures from each model to your widgets.

  • Step 4: Ensure that the linked dimensions are compatible and correctly display the measures from all models.

By following these steps, you‚Äôll be able to combine the data from the 4 BW queries and create a unified story with SAC.

Let me know if you need any further clarification!

entry.title: Re: How to trace the service confirmation document and it...
entry.content:
Hello @LDB 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these links Create Preliminary Billing Documents,  Event-Based Revenue Recognition & Journal Entry API Reference for more details. Below is a summary.

Yes, the preliminary billing document does not create accounting postings in public cloud. For that reason, provisional revenue recognition cannot be tied to the proforma itself.

In regard to your first question on service confirmation document. The answer is no and the reason is, revenue recognition in public cloud standard is tied to good issue or actual billing but not service confirmation.

On the second question regarding where you can view or trace the confirmation document. You can see the service confirmation document in the document flow app as shown in your screenshots, in your manage customer line item only if accounting postings exist and in the display document flow or sales order fulfillment monitor. The summary is, it is only traceable as a logistics reference and not in accounting.

Considering proforma billing is only meant for information you can choose between using a custom extension in BTP or Event-based revenue recognition to achieve provisional recognition with Proforma.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAC date filter in story: how to get most current dat...
entry.content:
‚úÖ Solution Options

‚úÖ Option 1: Use an Input Parameter with Default = Max(Date)

This is the best-practice method if you control the Calculation View design.

üîß Steps (HANA Calculation View):

  1. Create an Input Parameter:

    • Add an input parameter P_DATE of type Date.

    • Mark it as mandatory.

    • Set default value to MAX("Date") using a derived value or calculated default.

    Example expression (in default value definition):

    SELECT MAX("FACT_DATE") FROM "YOUR_TABLE"

    Or use a calculated column in the view that fetches the latest available date and assign it as the default value.

  2. Use P_DATE in a filter condition:

    • E.g., [FACT_DATE] = $P_DATE

  3. Expose P_DATE to SAC:

    • When SAC story loads, it will pre-fill the filter with the latest available date from the data.

  4. Allow override in SAC:

    • When users open the story, they can manually change the Input Parameter via the prompt panel or story input control.

üü¢ Pros:

  • Dynamic by design: Always uses the latest available date in the data.

  • User-friendly: Users can override it.

  • No SAC scripting needed.

üî¥ Cons:

  • Requires you to modify the Calculation View.

  • Only works if you use the Input Parameter in filtering logic inside the view.

‚úÖ Option 2: Add "Is Latest Date" Flag in the View

If you can't or don't want to use Input Parameters, you can:

  1. In your Calculation View, add a calculated column:

    CASE WHEN "FACT_DATE" = (SELECT MAX("FACT_DATE") FROM "YOUR_TABLE") THEN 'Y' ELSE 'N' END AS IS_LATEST_DATE

  2. In SAC:

    • Add a filter on IS_LATEST_DATE = 'Y' as the default.

    • Let users remove this filter and use a standard date filter instead.

üü¢ Pros:

  • Works with SAC filters (no parameters needed).

  • Gives full control to the story designer.

üî¥ Cons:

  • Still requires Calculation View change.

  • May have performance impact if MAX() isn't optimized.

‚úÖ Option 3: Use a "Latest Date" Table or Variable in the View

An enterprise-friendly method:

  1. Create a small HANA table/view: LATEST_FACT_DATE

    • Contains only 1 row: LATEST_DATE = '2025-07-31'

    • Update this table via ETL or script each time new data is loaded.

  2. In your Calculation View:

    • Join this table to your fact table.

    • Filter the fact table: FACT_DATE = LATEST_DATE

  3. In SAC:

    • This becomes the default behavior.

    • Users can remove the filter and see other dates.

üéØ SAC Implementation (Story-Side)

Once your Calculation View handles the default latest date logic:

  • In SAC:

    1. Create an Input Control for the Date (bound to the Input Parameter or Dimension).

    2. Set the default selection to:

      • Prompt default (if using Input Parameter), or

      • Filter IS_LATEST_DATE = Y (if using flag method).

    3. Allow users to change the selection freely.

üõë What Not to Do

  • Don‚Äôt try to rely on SAC‚Äôs system date ‚Äì it's not tied to the data and won't work if data is delayed (as in your case).

  • Don‚Äôt try to implement logic in the story alone ‚Äî SAC doesn‚Äôt support "dynamic default filters" based on max data values out of the box (especially with live models).

‚úÖ Summary

Option Description SAC Compatible User Override Recommended For

Input Parameter with MAX(Date)Default input param = latest date‚úÖ‚úÖCleanest solution
"Is Latest" Flag in ViewAdd a calculated column for latest flag‚úÖ‚úÖIf you can‚Äôt use params
Latest Date Join TableMaintain latest date in a separate table and join‚úÖ‚úÖIf you're using ETL
SAC Story Filter OnlyStatic filters in SAC story‚úÖ‚úÖ‚ùå Not dynamic

entry.title: SAP Enable Now: Issues with Automatic Content Visibility in Translation Workarea
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We‚Äôre currently facing a challenge with our SAP Enable Now setup and would appreciate any guidance or suggestions.

We‚Äôve created two separate Workareas:

  • Workarea 1 ‚Äì for content creation
  • Workarea 2 ‚Äì for translating the published content from Workarea 1

Our goal was to have all published content from Workarea 1 automatically visible in Workarea 2, so that our translation team could work directly from there. To achieve this, we configured Workarea 2 to use Workarea 1 as its Base Workarea, following the instructions provided under:

Manager > Administration > Server Settings > Connected Workarea > Enable Workarea Extensibility Feature

We understood that this setup should allow content from Workarea 1 to be visible and editable in Workarea 2. However, we‚Äôre encountering the following issues:

  • When opening Workarea 2 in Producer, the tree structure is incorrect or incomplete.
  • Changes made in Workarea 1 are not properly reflected in Workarea 2.
  • We attempted to manually import content using the archive import function, but even then, the structure remains incomplete and inconsistent.

Within this project, the setup is shown correctly for one of our consultants, however, on my side, it does not show up correctly. This will become an issue once we need to scale this setup to tens of authors.

Therefore, this setup is currently not usable for our translation workflow, and we urgently need a solution.

Has anyone experienced similar issues or found a reliable way to make the Base Workarea functionality work as expected for translation purposes?

Any help or advice would be greatly appreciated!

Best regards,
Janice

entry.title: Re: BP Legal Form changes not updating KNA1-GFORM
entry.content: This is a known issue where the KNA1-GFORM field does not update through the standard CVI synchronization process during a change request, even though other fields do. This is because the field is not actively managed for subsequent updates. The recommended solution is to implement a Business Add-In (BAdI), such as CVI_CUSTOM_MAPPER, to manually update the KNA1-GFORM field directly with the new value during the CVI synchronization process.

entry.title: 2H 2025 SuccessFactors Release Schedule
entry.content:
2H 2025 SuccessFactors Release Dates

Key Dates: 2H 2025

MilestoneDate
Preview Release WindowOctober 13, 2025
Production Release WindowNovember 14-16, 2025
  • Preview is when the upcoming changes/features are available in non-productive instances so you can test.
  • Production is when changes go live in customer production environments.

SAP classifies new release items into four enablement categories:

  • Customer Configured ‚Üí Needs manual setup by the customer.

  • Contact Product Support ‚Üí Activation/troubleshooting by SAP Support.

  • Contact Enablement Partner ‚Üí Setup help from your partner.

  • Contact CEE / Account Manager ‚Üí Enabled via your SAP Contact Customer Engagement Executive or Account Manager.

  • Automatically On ‚Üí Delivered by default, no setup needed.

You need to align with your client or business stakeholders to determine which features should be adopted immediately and which should be put on hold for later.

With the 1H 2025 release, SAP SuccessFactors provides a clear framework to help customers understand how new features are enabled, what actions are required, and their lifecycle status.

 

DimensionCategoriesPurpose
Enablement
  • Customer Configured
  • Contact Product Support
  • Contact Enablement Partner
  • Contact CEE/Account Manager
  • Automatically On
Defines how a feature becomes available to you ‚Äì whether it requires manual configuration, assistance, or is enabled by default.

Actions

  • Info Only
  • Not Applicable
  • Recommended
  • Required
Explains what you need to do ‚Äì from awareness only, to mandatory adoption.
Lifecycle
  • General Availability
  • Deprecated
  • Deleted
Shows the current and future state of a feature ‚Äì whether it‚Äôs active, being phased out, or fully removed.

Regards,

Mahnoor Naseem

SAP SuccessFactors Consultant

If you found this blog useful please consider giving it a Kudos

entry.title: Building Low-code/No-code SAP CPQ extension using SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1)
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP CPQ (Configure Price Quote) is a software solution that allows customers to configure products and services, set up pricing and discounts, generate accurate quotes, and create custom proposals. While offering a great deal of functionality out-of-the-box, SAP CPQ can also be easily extended and customized, to support custom, and often unique, business processes and procedures.

One way in which SAP CPQ can be extended is by developing an external extension application that is integrated with SAP CPQ using standard integration mechanisms (REST APIs, events, webhook notifications etc.). This approach, also known as side-by-side extensibility, has several distinctive benefits: increased flexibility in terms of technological choice, possibility of using dedicated resources, better performance due to limited scope and many more.

This series of blog posts will explore several ways for building and deploying side-by-side extensions of SAP CPQ, using the SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and various tools offered by that platform. In this first of the blog posts, we will see how we can use SAP Build Process Automation for building an extension that can be invoked from SAP CPQ by calling its dedicated API endpoint.

 

Overview of the solution

SAP Build Process Automation is a low-code/no-code solution that enables you to automate workflow processes without writing a single line of code, just by using a graphical, drag-and-drop editor. It is an ideal solution for developing both simple extensions, as well as complex business process applications. To learn more about SAP Build Process Automation, please check the official documentation.

Overview of the solution (including Part 1 and Part 2)

This blog post will demonstrate how to start an SAP Build Process Automation process from SAP CPQ global script using the concept of API Triggers. API Trigger represents an HTTP endpoint that can be invoked using the standard mechanism, and that will cause the new process instance to be started. API Triggers also allow you to , via the body of the HTTP request, specify the inputs that will be used for starting the process instance.

By the end of this blog post, I hope that I will be able to demonstrate how easy it is to start SAP Build Process Automation processes from SAP CPQ, and how this can be useful for extending the basic SAP CPQ functionality.

As an example extension application that we want to integrate with SAP CPQ, we are going to use a simple business process involving legal check of created quotes. The process triggers manual check based on the market associated with the quote, and allows the responsible persons to decide whether quote should be accepted or rejected from the legal perspective. The decision then triggers invocation of appropriate custom CPQ action, something that is described in the Part 2 of this series.

Example SAP Build Process Automation process used in this blog post series

Please note that, in this blog post, I assume that you are familiar with the basics of using SAP Build Process Automation. If that is not the case, please check the excellent "Creating Processes and Automations with SAP Build Process Automation" learning journey at SAP Learning.

 

Defining an API trigger for your SAP Build Process Automation process

To define a new API Trigger for your SAP Build Process Automation process, navigate to the process overview screen and select Add a Trigger.

Then, select the API Trigger.

Next, specify a descriptive name and identifier for this new API Trigger, and click on Create button.

You will see a newly defined API trigger as the first step in your SAP Build Process Automation process. To define inputs for your SAP Build Process Automation process (and, consequently, parameters for the API Trigger), click on the << to show the Process Details pane.

Here, click on Variables, and then on Configure button related to Process Inputs. Please note that if, prior to adding an API Trigger, you have already defined the rest of your process, Process Inputs will be automatically populated, which significantly simplifies the configuration. Still, even in that case, you can double-check the generated Process Inputs and make changes if necessary.

This will display the Configure Process Inputs popup, where you can define all the process inputs. To add a new input, click on the Add Input button, and specify the following:

  • Descriptive Name of the input parameter
  • Unique Identifier of the input parameter (unique for the concrete process you are configuring). This identifier will be used later, when we define a JSON object that will be sent as a request body when making a HTTP call to your SAP Build Process Automation process.
  • Optional Description of the input parameter
  • Type of the input parameter
  • Whether input parameter is Required or represents a List of values

After defining all the input parameters for the process, click on the Apply to make the changes.

You can consume these process input parameters in the same way as you would consume output of any other process step in the project: you can display them on the form, use them as input parameters for another action etc.  In our example, an action step is the first step of the process, so we can use process input parameters as the values of the input fields of the action by selecting them in the Process Content pane (under the Process Inputs section). These fields will have the corresponding types, according to the way you have configured them in the previous step.

 

Deploying SAP Build Process Automation project

Before being able to invoke your SAP Build Process Automation process via an HTTP call, you need to deploy your SAP Build Process Automation project in a desired environment (before doing that, please make sure that you have released a version of your project, as described in documentation).

The process of deploying SAP Build Process Automation project is described in detail in official documentation. When deploying the project, you will be notified about the creation of new triggers; just confirm by clicking on Deploy button.

 

Getting the instance endpoint and authentication data

To connect SAP CPQ with SAP Build Process Automation, it is necessary to get the endpoint and authentication data for your SAP Build Process Automation instance from the SAP BTP subaccount where that instance is located. To do so, go to the subaccount in BTP Cockpit, select Services -> Instances and Subscriptions, and then navigate the SAP Build Process Automation instance and click on > to display the instance details. (In case you currently don't have an instance of SAP Build Process Automation service available, you can create one by clicking the blue Create button in the top left corner of the screen and following the instructions)

Next, service key needs to be created, if there is none already available. Click on the Create button in the Service Keys section, enter the descriptive Service Key Name and click Create again.

Once service key is created, click on ‚Ä¶ button to show the menu, and then select View to display the endpoint and credentials information.

From the popup window displaying the credentials:

  • Note the uaa.clientid and uaa.clientsecret, representing the OAuth 2.0 client credentials used for obtaining access token that needs to be provided when accessing the API of your SAP Build Process Automation instance
  • Note the uaa.url, representing the base URL of the OAuth 2.0 authorization server used for obtaining access token that needs to be provided when accessing the API of your SAP Build Process Automation instance

After obtaining information from the service key, new Credential Management entry in the SAP CPQ needs to be created. In the SAP CPQ setup, go to Security -> Credential Management and click on New Entry:

  • Specify a descriptive Name for this entry, and make sure to note it down, because it will be used in later steps
  • Select Credential as an entry Type
  • For the Identifier field, use the value of uaa.clientid field obtained in the previous step
  • For the Secret field, use the value of uaa.clientsecret field obtained in the previous step

Once done, click Save.

Make sure to activate the newly created entry by clicking on the Active slider button.

After activating, slider should be positioned on the right.

 

Calling SAP Build Process Automation process from SAP CPQ global script

Two more pieces of information are needed before you will be able to call SAP Build Process Automation process from SAP CPQ: URL of the SAP Build Process Automation API endpoint and the unique identifier of your process. To find these, navigate your SAP Build Process Automation instance and select SAP Build Lobby -> Control Tower -> Environments. Then, select the environments where you have deployed your process.

Then, select Triggers and click on ‚Ä¶ button associated with the API Trigger you have created for your process. Select View option, and the popup window will be displayed.

From this window, note the URL value, as well as the value of the definitionId field of the JSON found in the Payload textbox.

Now we have all the needed information to implement a call to your process in an SAP CPQ global script. If you are not familiar with the concept of global scripts, they are a piece of custom code (written in IronPython) that can be attached to all kinds of events in SAP CPQ. Once the event has occurred, the global script is automatically executed. For more information about global scripts, please check the official documentation.

Invoking an SAP Build Process Automation process from global script requires two things: fetching an access token and making an HTTP call that will start the process itself. Fetching an access token can be done in the following way (here, we have extracted it into a separate method):

def fetch_access_token():
    credentials_store_entry = '<CREDENTIAL_MANAGEMENT_ENTRY_NAME>'
    token_endpoint = '<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_AS_URL>/oauth/token'
    response = AuthorizedRestClient.GetClientCredentialsGrantOAuthToken(credentials_store_entry, token_endpoint)
    return response['access_token']

You need to substitute:

  • <CREDENTIAL_MANAGEMENT_ENTRY_NAME> with the Name of the Credential Management entry you have created in SAP CPQ in the previous step
  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_AS_URL> with the value of the uaa.url field extracted from the service key in one of the previous steps (please note that the final token_endpoint is a concatenation of this value and '/oauth/token')

Now, to invoke an SAP Build Process Automation process, you can use the following snippet (of course, modified for your concrete business need):

url = '<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_ENDPOINT_API_URL>'
data = {
  "definitionId": "<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_ID>",
  "context": <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_INPUT_AS_JSON>
}
headers = { 'Authorization': 'Bearer {}'.format(fetch_access_token()) }
response = RestClient.Post(url, data, headers)
# handle the response (check for errors, etc.)

You need to substitute:

  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_ENDPOINT_API_URL> with the value of the URL you have just extracted from the popup window in the Triggers section
  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_ID> with the value of the definitionId field you have just extracted from the popup window in the Triggers section
  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_INPUT_AS_JSON> with a JSON object that matches the process inputs you have configured in one of the previous steps (with the Identifier of the input parameter representing name in the name-value pair)

For example, let's say that we have configured the following process inputs:

Then, our call would look like this:

url = '<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_ENDPOINT_API_URL>'
data = {
  "definitionId": "<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_ID>",
  "context": {
    "quoteID": 12345 # or, for example context.Quote.Id
  }
}
headers = { 'Authorization': 'Bearer {}'.format(fetch_access_token()) }
response = RestClient.Post(url, data, headers)
# handle the response (check for errors, etc.)

(For more information, please consult the official documentation and API specification.)

That's it!

Conclusion

SAP Build Process Automation is a low-code/no-code solution that can be used for the development of side-by-side extensions of SAP CPQ. Side-by-side extensions can help you in customizing SAP CPQ to support your concrete business processes and requirements. In this blog post, we have demonstrated the way these extensions can be invoked from SAP CPQ. In the next post in the series, we will show you how SAP Build Process Automation processes can invoke SAP CPQ API in a secure and reliable way.

Resources

  • "Creating Processes and Automations with SAP Build Process Automation" learning journey at SAP Learning
  • API specification

entry.title: Re: Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content: To understand the organizational structure in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, it is essential to know the function of each organizational unit. Just like a family has guardians, supervisors, and dependents, SAP units have specific roles. Profitability is managed through CO-PA (Controlling ‚Äì Profitability Analysis), where the Operating Concern sits at the top, collecting all cost information. In Public Cloud, one operating concern (A000) and one controlling area (A000) are predefined. Financial transactions are recorded at the company code level, the smallest FI unit, which forms the backbone for MM and SD integration. Plants, assigned to company codes, handle production activities and record costs, while Sales & Distribution (SD) tracks revenue through sales organizations and sales areas, ensuring revenue flows into CO-PA. Purchasing organizations manage procurement, either centralized or decentralized, and under the controlling area, cost centers and profit centers track expenses and profitability. Materials move from procurement or production to storage locations, then through shipping points to the customer, translating operations into financial results. MM and SD represent opposite flows‚Äîcosts and revenues‚Äîwhich converge in CO-PA for profitability analysis. A strong organizational structure ensures that financial and operational data is correctly captured, integrated, and reported. In SAP Public Cloud, these units are predefined and must be configured carefully, as no consultant can begin module configuration without first establishing the organizational structure.    myccpay com

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment on SAP Cloud Infrastructure
entry.content:
With the availability of SAP BTP ABAP Environment on SAP Cloud Infrastructure on September 19th 2025, Steampunk has reached the next milestone in the multi-hyperscaler availability for our customers, partners and SAP products using Steampunk.

The following region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is now supported by SAP BTP and Steampunk:

  • Europe (Frankfurt) - EU-only access 

This new region complements the already existing regions on AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud. Please find an overview about all supported hyprscalers and regions in the SAP Discovery Center.

The second region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is planned in Q4/2025 in China (Shanghai). We will update and enhance the plan of further data centers regularly in the Roadmap Explorer.  

 

Available Service Plans

All well-established service plans standard, build-runtime, saas_oem, and free are available in the new region.

 

How to use Steampunk on SAP Cloud Infrastructure

To create a new Steampunk system on SAP Cloud Infrastructure, open the SAP BTP Cockpit and create (or use) a subaccount for the respective SAP Cloud Infrastructure region cf-xx01. Follow the steps as explained in the Steampunk documentation.

 

References

Please refer to the following additional references:

  • SAP Discovery Center for all supported providers, service plans and regions
  • Roadmap information for Steampunk infrastructure
  • SAP Community page for Steampunk

entry.title: Can I print to PDF and merge using Adobe Acrobat in SAP?
entry.content:
I needs assistance printing multiple delivery notes to PDF.

I am currently using Adobe Acrobat Pro. However, when printing to PDF, I receive multiple print dialog boxes‚Äîone for each delivery note‚Äîand must manually confirm each one to save them individually.

Previously, I she used to have PDFCreator, which allowed me to select multiple delivery notes, print to PDF, and automatically merge them into a single PDF file.

Unfortunately, PDFCreator is now blocked by CrowdStrike due to a detected threat, so it cannot be used.
 
I would like to know if it's possible to replicate this functionality using Adobe Acrobat Pro, so that all selected documents can be saved as a single PDF without needing to confirm each one individually.

entry.title: Migrating SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite (CPI): A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Introduction


As organizations move towards cloud-based integration platforms, migrating from SAP Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite (CPI) becomes essential. This blog will walk you through the key steps of this migration, focusing on:

  • Connecting SAP PO to SAP Cloud Connector And adding SAP PO in SAP Integration Suite (CPI)

  • Importing Message Mappings from SAP PO

  • Importing dependent objects of the Message Mapping,  such as Imported Archives and Function Libraries

 

‚Äå‚Äå Step 1: Connecting SAP PO to Cloud Connector

Since SAP PO is an on-premise system, we use SAP Cloud Connector to securely connect SAP CPI (cloud) to the SAP PO environment. The Cloud Connector acts as a secure tunnel between cloud applications and on-premise systems without exposing them directly to the internet.

  1. Install SAP Cloud Connector  on the same network as SAP PO (for testing install on your system).

  2. Connect Cloud Connector to your SAP BTP subaccount (SAP CPI tenant).
    Establishing a Connection Between Cloud Connector and Subaccount 

  3. Login to the SAP Cloud Connector and select the subaccount and click on Cloud to On-Premises.

  4. Add the SAP PO System in Cloud Connector.

    Back-end Type: ABAP System
    Protocol: HTTP
    Internal Host: *PO Sytem Host Name without http://*
    Internal Port: *PO Sytem port*
    Virtual Host: *Enter a desired virtual hostname. This will be used when connecting from Integration suite.*
    Virtual Port: *Enter a desired port*
    Allow Principal Propagation: check‚úîÔ∏è
    Principal Type:Kerberos
    Host in Request Header: Use Virtual Host
    Next ==> Next==>
    Check Internal Host: check‚úîÔ∏è
    Finish

     

  5. Add resources path by clicking on the + icon and enter / select Path and all Sub-Paths ==> Save.

  6.  Check whether the added SAP PO system is reachable.

    If it's not, cross-check the host and port. Ensure that both the SAP PO system and the Cloud Connector are accessible through the same network.

  7.  Now we have successfully connected to SAP PO system from SAP Cloud Connector.

Step 2: Connecting SAP PO  to SAP Integration Suite(CPI) Through SAP Cloud Connector

 

  1. Login to the Integration suite, Go to settings ==> Integrations==> select System Tab==> click on +  to add the SAP PO Sytem.

  2. Enter the details of System Overview and Integration Directory.

    In the Address box, enter the Virtual Host and Port with http://, as maintained in the Cloud Connector.
    If your PO System uses the same address for both the Integration Directory and the ES Repository, check the corresponding checkbox‚úîÔ∏è. Otherwise, specify them separately. 
  3. Test the connectivity between Integration suite and SAP PO system.

  4.  Now we have successfully connected to SAP PO system from Integration suite.

Step 3: Importing Message Mappings from SAP PO to SAP CPI

  1.  Login to the Integration suite and go to your package and click on Add message mapping. Selcet ES Repository and select the added SAP PO System and connect.

  2.  Select the required message mapping and click on next.

  3.   To import Message mappings there are some prerequisites:

    Based on your message mapping, you may have dependent resources such as a Function Library, Imported Archive, WSDL, or XSD. 

    WSDL and XSD files are imported automatically along with the message mapping. However, Function Libraries and Imported Archives must be imported separately.

    After selecting the message mapping, you will be able to see the list of dependent resources. You must import the required resources (Function Library and Imported Archive) first; otherwise, the message mapping cannot be imported successfully.

     

 

  1. Importing Dependent Objects: Function Libraries
    1. Create a function library artifact, click on "Upload," connect to the SAP PO system, select your function libraries, save, and then deploy.

    2.  Create a Imported Archives artifact, click on "Upload," connect to the SAP PO system, select your Imported Archives, save, and then deploy.

           4. Since the dependent objects have been imported, we can now import the message mapping. Add the message                               mapping artifact, select the ES Repository, choose the added SAP PO system, connect, select the message mapping,                     click "Next," and then select the dependent objects that were imported as separate artifacts.

5. Click on "Select" and choose the required function library artifact.

6. If the status shows "Already Existing," click on it and select "Reuse Existing Resource.

 

7. Next, click on "Select" and choose the required imported archive artifact. Then, click "Submit" to import the message      mapping.

 8.  Now the Message Mapping is successfully imported to Integration suite from SAP PO system.

 

Conclusion

Migrating from SAP PO to SAP CPI goes beyond a simple technical shift‚Äîit‚Äôs an opportunity to modernize integration landscapes, adopt cloud-first patterns, and leverage the flexibility of SAP BTP. By carefully setting up connectivity through the Cloud Connector, systematically migrating message mappings, and addressing dependencies like archives and function libraries, you can ensure a smooth and reliable transition.

A phased migration approach, combined with thorough testing and best practices, will help minimize risk and maximize value. This journey not only preserves existing investments but also sets the stage for future-ready integrations.

Stay tuned for my upcoming blogs, where I‚Äôll deep dive into adapter migration strategies and lessons learned from real project experiences. üöÄ

entry.title: Posting date in Manage Bank Statements app
entry.content:
When we create the statement manually, the posting date may or may not coincide with the value date, i.e., we can manually change the posting date, which does not have to be the same as the statement date.

We would like to know if there is an option for when we upload the statement via Excel, as well as when we do so via the upload provided by the bank, whereby we can modify the posting date and it does not have to be the statement date.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Posting date in Manage Bank Statements app
entry.content:
I understand that you are looking for clarification regarding the ability to modify the posting date when uploading bank statements via Excel or through the bank's upload functionality.

When creating a bank statement manually using the spreadsheet template, you can specify the desired posting date by entering it in the Posting Date column. This allows you to set a posting date that is different from the bank statement date.

However, for bank statement imports using bank statement files, the posting date is determined directly from the file.

For further details, you may refer to the resource titled Understanding Date Determination in Bank Statement available on the SAP Community.

entry.title: Re: Set up your SAP S/4HANA system for EAM Inspection Checklists
entry.content:
Hi Tshering Yangdon,

see my answers below -->, please:

1. Is it mandatory to create and assign a task list type to Material Code under the Quality Management view? 
--> There is no task list type for material master in 'Insp. Setup'..

 2. Why do we need to create the Inspection plan with respect to the Material Code, as we already have a Maintenance plan created against Equipment with the task list assigned to it? - If I select 1000 pieces of equipment, do I need to create 1000 material codes to create the Inspection Plan? 
--> The material code/material number is just a technical necessity for the QM inspection process to work. Create just ONE "dummy" material number and ONE inspection type. You use it for ALL inspection plans! It's a little one-time effort to enable the process.
Remark: if you use different sets of usages decisions, you use different inspection types with origin 89. Example:
Inspection type C1 with usage decision options: okay/not okay
Inspection type C2 with usage decision options: okay/not okay/okay with post-work

--> It makes sense to have the inspection plan defined separately from your PM task list in the maintenance plan. You define an inspection plan for a type of equipment/type of activity ONCE. Then, this one inspection plan is found for all combinations of task lists operations with same check list type and equipments of same equipment class. Otherwise, you would need to define the inspection items for ALL combinations of task lists and equipment types in the task list operations with the need to create much more master data.

3. Could you please mention the critical conditions for generating the inspection lots under the checklist?
--> What do you mean by that. Important are two settings to find the correct inspection plan for you equipment:
1: equipment class and (optional) equipment class value(s) - indicates the type of equipment, e. g. elevator/pump/railway switch for which an inspection plan should be found
2: checklist type at operation - indicates WHAT is to be checked at your equipment, e. g. monthly/annual check mechanical/electric parts. This way, you are able to find different inspection plans for the same type of equipment according to the WHAT indication.

Best Regards, Uwe
